Negative energy means negative mass, which, through a simple thought experiment explained to me by my friend, means infinite energy. Just follow this:

The particle with negative mass would be repelled by the particle with positive mass, and vice-versa because of gravity. However, since a = F/m, and m is negative, a is negative, meaning the particle with negative mass would accelerate TOWARDS the one with positive mass, causing the pair to accelerate to the speed of light. No.

Virtual particles are instead created by an uncertainty between energy (and thus mass) and time: as long as the uncertainty is below a certain threshold (i.e. the time is short enough), a particle-antiparticle pair of x mass (x being related to the time period) can form. However, on the event horizon, the pair cannot annihilate, leading to the mass of the escaping particle being taken from the black hole. Physics had a bit of an accident, and thus makes up for it.

You'd actually be OK falling into an SMBH (Supermassive Black Hole) because the tidal forces would be relatively small. Well... I lied. You wouldn't be OK. If it had an accretion disk, you'd be roasted, and, because of a sphere of orbiting photons on the event horizon, you'd be fried. Not mentioning the fact that the incoming visible light hitting you near (and past) the event horizon would be so blue shifted that you'd get toasted. Other than the radiation, you'd be fine. That's not much comfort, is it?

It's not that quantum mechanics and general relativity don't work together -- that is a common misconception -- but that there is no experimentally verified theory of quantum gravity. By this I mean we can combine general relativity together with quantum field theory to produce quantum field theory in curved space; however, this treats gravity classically, in the sense that we cannot 'quantize' it. Just like we can quantize electromagnetic waves to get quantized packets called photons.
Actually, we can quantize gravity -- gravitons -- but it all falls apart on the Planck scale!
Not trying to be super pedantic, just thought I'd share :)
Long story short -- it's a confusing mess!

It's an interesting question: do black holes actually exist? Because from the point of view of an outside observer, it takes an infinite amount of time for a particle to fall into the black hole (though, from the point of view of the infalling particle it takes a finite amount of time). Likewise, from our point of view it takes an infinite amount of time for the star to actually collapse into the black hole, though from the point of view of the star itself it takes a finite amount of time.

Isn't the conclusion that black holes cannot exist, though objects arbitrarily close to a black hole (and all but indistinguishable from one) can? Even worse, if from the point of view of an outside observer it takes an infinite amount of time for a particle to reach the black hole, but a finite amount of time for the black hole to evaporate - isn't the conclusion that no particle can actually fall into the black hole? Either it will impact the collapsing star, or the star will evaporate before the particle reaches it.

The bit about how a black hole's gravity is too strong for light to escape is kinda incorrect. Light can escape pretty much any gravitational field, since nothing can stop it from traveling as fast as it does. But when it gets close to a black hole, things get weird. The closer you are to a black hole, the slower time will appear to run for you from an outside perspective.  So if a beam of light is shot radially outwards from a point just above the event horizon, it WOULD escape, but since time is literally slower the closer you are to the black hole, the light particle's wavelength would get stretched as it goes further out and time starts to quicken for it again. The wavelength of light determines what color our eyes perceive it as, so as the wavelength lengthens, the light will turn more red. But once it turns "too red", it will become completely imperceptible to our eyes, because its wavelength has dropped below the range that our eyes can detect. So it escapes,we just cant see it.

There's this one that suggests that beyond the event horizon, space is actually larger... like.. a LOT larger. They also went into detail about the 'spaghettification'... Their argument was that since time is stretched as well as space, then it would 'appear' that a person would be spaghettified to someone observing from a distance, but for the person going through it, they would see themselves stretch, but only because their perceived time became different than the actual time in the area of space they're in. They would, in a sense, simply fall as one would if they jumped off of a building (with a parachute) or out of a plane. Then it was argued if they would actually land on the 'surface' of the black hole, or if, because of the space expansion within the event horizon, they would simply float between the event horizon and the singularity.

Thanks for a very good basic description of what is happening near the horizon of a black hole.  During my career in astrophysics, General Relativity at its intersection with Quantum Mechanics (i.e., the strong field cases; neutron stars and black holes) was/is my area of interest.  Just to add a little more intrigue to this topic; the mass of a black hole is only an "apparent" mass that is measured by a remote observer due to its effect on the object's surroundings.  Within the horizon the is no actual mass at all.  All that is left is the severely warped spacetime.  Recalling Einstein's mass-energy equivalence; all of the mass/energy that has crossed the horizon has been used up warping the spacetime within the black hole.  Additionally, due to the essentially infinite warping of spacetime at the central singularity the diameter/radius of the horizon as measured, again, by a remote observer is misleading.  If it were possible (which it is not) for someone to enter the black hole and cross it the distance that would actually need to be traversed would be enormous (essentially, again, infinite).  That is why we normally speak not of the horizon's radius but, instead, of its circumference which is unambiguous.  Thanks again for a wonderful video.

0:53 "But light always travels at the speed of light". That's a common misconception. The speed of light in vacuum is NOT constant. And that's exactly what gives rise to gravity. It has nothing to do with the light travelling in a curved path as she described.
